title: What’s South of the South Pole? - Quora

response.answer_text: You cannot go South of the South pole. When you are at the South pole there is only one compass direction and it is North. The poles lie at latitude 90 deg. North and 90 deg South latitude. It is no longer a line of latitude it is a singular point. It is a dot. At that point all lines of longitude meet as well. To travel in any direction away from that dot will require a movement North. Once you move away from the pole you will no longer be at lat 90 deg S and the options of traveling in an Eastward, Westward, Southward, and Northward direction will return.

Nothing. How Dan you go ‘south's of the furthest south? You cannot! At the South Geographic Pole there is NO East or West. The one and only direction is NORTH! At the North Geographic guess what? There is NO East or West. The only direction is SOUTH. You want to travel away from the pole you have to do so using polar coordinates - a bearing and a distance. After about 111 km you will have travelled to approximately latitude 89 degrees.

Please understand the concept of a limit. The South Pole is defined as the southernmost point on the planet, just as the North Pole is defined as the northernmost point on the planet. So, there can be no answer to your question. Sorry, I don’t mean to be unkind, just factual.

There is nothing South of the Geographic South Pole. The South Pole by definition is the southernmost point on Earth. Meanwhile, the magnetic south pole is slightly north of the coast of Antarctica. This means that Antarctica is South of the Magnetic South Pole

Nothing. It is 90 degrees south, as far south as one can get, measurement-wise. If you follow a longitude line south and reach the South Pole and then keep going, you will start going north again on the opposite side of the earth 180 degrees from where you went south in the first place.
If you can imaginge a line from Earth’s center through the South Pole it continues through the atmosphere into space. So south of the South Pole there first some air, then a lot of space.
